22-11707   BRASHER, J., Concurring  1 
BRASHER, Circuit Judge, concurring: 
I concur in the Courtโs opinion. I write separately to focus 
on the plaintiffsโ equal protection claim.  
The resolution of an equal protection claim often turns on 
the level of scrutiny that we applyโrational basis, intermediate, or 
strict. The plaintiffs argue that the statute classifies based on sex, 
which warrants intermediate scrutiny. The Court rejects that argu-
ment, and, after much deliberation and research, I agree. Ala-
bamaโs statute does not treat one sex differently than the other. It 
does not use sex as a proxy for some more germane classification. 
And it is not based on a sex stereotype. Instead, I think the law is 
best read to classifyโnot based on sexโbut as between minors 
who want puberty blockers and hormones to treat a โdiscordance 
between their sex and their internal sense of identity,โ Ala. Code 
ยง 26-26-2(2), and those minors who want these drugs to treat a dif-
ferent condition.  
But even if the statute did discriminate based on sex, I think 
it is likely to satisfy intermediate scrutiny. If Alabamaโs statute in-
volves a sex-based classification that triggers heightened scrutiny, 
it does so because it is otherwise impossible to regulate these drugs 
differently when they are prescribed as a treatment for gender dys-
phoria than when they are prescribed for other purposes. As long 
as the state has a substantial justification for regulating differently 
the use of puberty blockers and hormones for different purposes, 
then I think this law satisfies intermediate scrutiny. 
 

Case 2:22-cv-00184-LCB-CWB   Document 312   Filed 08/30/23   Page 53 of 65
USCA11 Case: 22-11707     Document: 125-1     Date Filed: 08/21/2023     Page: 51 of 59
2  BRASHER, J., Concurring  22-11707 
I.    
Iโll start with the level of scrutiny that applies to this law. We 
should be cautious when we are asked to extend heightened scru-
tiny to novel facts like these. As Justice Stevens explained in one of 
the Courtโs leading cases on sex discrimination, the text of the 
Equal Protection Clause does not subject state laws to different lev-
els of judicial scrutiny. See Craig v. Boren, 429 U.S. 190, 211โ12 (1976) 
(Stevens, J., concurring). The Clause โrequires every State to gov-
ern impartially,โ and it โdoes not direct the courts to apply one 
standard of review in some cases and a different standard in other 
cases.โ Id.; see also United States v. Virginia, 518 U.S. 515, 570 (1996) 
(Scalia, J., dissenting) (calling tiers of scrutiny โmade-up testsโ); 
Whole  Womanโs  Health  v.  Hellerstedt,  579  U.S.  582,  638  (2016) 
(Thomas,  J.,  dissenting)  (calling  tiers  of  scrutiny  โincreasingly 
meaningless  . . .  formalismโ).  Moreover,  some  of  the Supreme 
Courtโs most recent (and significant) equal protection precedents 
donโt apply the tiers of scrutiny. E.g., Obergefell v. Hodges, 576 U.S. 
644, 672โ76 (2015). 
Nonetheless, the Supreme Court has established the tiers of 
scrutiny, and lower courts must apply that doctrine the best we 
can. In doing so, I think we must appreciate that the tiers of scru-
tiny are โno more scientific than their names suggest.โ Virginia, 518 
U.S. at 567 (Scalia, J., dissenting). They should be โguidelines in-
forming our approach to the case at hand, not tests to be mechani-
cally applied.โ Williams-Yulee v. Fla. Bar, 575 U.S. 433, 457 (2015) 
(Breyer, J., concurring). To that end, when we are asked to apply 
 

Case 2:22-cv-00184-LCB-CWB   Document 312   Filed 08/30/23   Page 54 of 65
USCA11 Case: 22-11707     Document: 125-1     Date Filed: 08/21/2023     Page: 52 of 59
22-11707   BRASHER, J., Concurring  3 
heightened scrutiny on novel facts, we need to ensure that the pur-
poses of the doctrine warrant that approach.  
In my view, many judges have mechanically applied inter-
mediate scrutiny to laws like Alabamaโs without considering the 
reasons we subject sex classifications to heightened scrutiny. Con-
sider the Eighth Circuitโs decision in Brandt by & through Brandt v. 
Rutledge, 47 F.4th 661 (8th Cir. 2022). There, the court concluded 
that Arkansasโs comparable law discriminates based on sex be-
cause, referring to cross-sex hormones, it said that โmedical proce-
dures that are permitted for a minor of one sex are prohibited for a 
minor of another sex.โ Id. at 669. But the court ignored the lawโs 
ban on puberty blockers, which applies the same way to both sexes. 
And, more fundamentally, the court did not explain how applying 
heightened scrutiny to a law that regulates sex-specific medical in-
terventions is consistent with the reasons the Supreme Court cre-
ated that standard. 
Turning back to this case, Alabamaโs law is replete with sex-
related language. But, even though the statute uses sex-related lan-
guage, I think it is wrong to say that the statute classifies based on 
sex. The law regulates drugs that treat a โdiscordance between [an 
individualโs] sex and their internal sense of identity.โ Ala. Code 
ยง 26-26-2(2). The law defines โsexโ as โ[t]he biological state of being 
male or female, based on the individualโs sex organs, chromo-
somes, and endogenous hormone profiles.โ Id. ยง 26-26-3(3). Then 
the law prohibits various treatments โfor the purpose of attempting 
to alter the appearance of or affirm the minorโs perception of his or 
 

Case 2:22-cv-00184-LCB-CWB   Document 312   Filed 08/30/23   Page 55 of 65
USCA11 Case: 22-11707     Document: 125-1     Date Filed: 08/21/2023     Page: 53 of 59
4  BRASHER, J., Concurring  22-11707 
her gender or sex, if that appearance or perception is inconsistent 
with the minorโs sex as defined in this [act].โ Id. ยง 26-26-4(a). 
I see the word โsexโ in this law. But I donโt see a sex classifi-
cationโat least, not as the idea of a sex classification appears in our 
equal-protection caselaw. Instead, it seems to me that this sex-re-
lated language classifies between, on the one hand, those minors 
who want these drugs to treat a โdiscordance between their sex and 
their internal sense of identityโ and, on the other hand, those mi-
nors who want these drugs to treat a different condition. The Equal 
Protection Clause โis essentially a direction that all persons simi-
larly  situated  should  be  treated  alike.โ  City of Cleburne, Tex. v. 
Cleburne Living Ctr., 473 U.S. 432, 439 (1985). So the right question 
under the Equal Protection Clause is whether these two groupsโ
those who want to use these drugs to treat a discordance between 
their sex and gender identity and those who want to use these 
drugs to treat other conditionsโare similarly situated.  
That question isnโt one that seems suited to heightened scru-
tiny. The Equal Protection Clause prohibits โgiv[ing] a mandatory 
preference to members of either sex over members of the other.โ 
Reed v. Reed, 404 U.S. 71, 76 (1971). We apply heightened scrutiny 
to sex classifications because of an intuition that, โ[r]ather than rest-
ing on meaningful considerations, statutes distributing benefits and 
burdens between the sexes in different ways very likely reflect out-
moded notions of the relative capabilities of men and women.โ City 
of Cleburne, 473 U.S. at 441. When we apply heightened scrutiny to 
a  statute  that  classifies  based  on  sex,  the  point  is  to  ascertain 
 

Case 2:22-cv-00184-LCB-CWB   Document 312   Filed 08/30/23   Page 56 of 65
USCA11 Case: 22-11707     Document: 125-1     Date Filed: 08/21/2023     Page: 54 of 59
22-11707   BRASHER, J., Concurring  5 
whether the classification is based on โtraditional, often inaccurate, 
assumptions about the proper roles of men and women.โ Miss. 
Univ. for Women v. Hogan, 458 U.S. 718, 725โ26 (1982). We are also 
seeking to ensure that sex is not being used as an โinaccurate proxy 
for other, more germane bases of classification.โ Craig, 429 U.S. at 
198.  
None of these rationales apply to the line drawn in Ala-
bamaโs statute. It doesnโt distribute benefits or burdens between 
men and women or arguably use sex as a proxy for other interests. 
It bans a course of treatmentโpuberty blockers and hormonesโ
for a particular condition that affects both boys and girls. Another 
way to think about it: an injunction against the enforcement of Al-
abamaโs law under equal-protection principles will not equalize 
burdens or benefits between girls and boys. It will not require the 
government to treat boys and girls the same. It will merely force 
Alabama to either ban puberty blockers and hormones for all pur-
poses or allow them for all purposes. 
For its part, the district court applied heightened scrutiny on 
the theory that Alabamaโs statute discriminates based on a sex ste-
reotype because it targets medical interventions for transgender 
people, i.e., those who feel a โdiscordance between their sex and 
their internal sense of identity.โ The district court cited Glenn v. 
Brumby, 663 F.3d 1312, 1320 (11th Cir. 2011), for this proposition, 
but I think it misread that precedent.1 In Glenn, we concluded that 
 
1 I donโt fault the district court for reaching the conclusion that it did. The 
district court did an admirable job with a difficult case on an expedited 
 

Case 2:22-cv-00184-LCB-CWB   Document 312   Filed 08/30/23   Page 57 of 65
USCA11 Case: 22-11707     Document: 125-1     Date Filed: 08/21/2023     Page: 55 of 59
6  BRASHER, J., Concurring  22-11707 
a  public  employer  engaged  in  sex  discrimination  by  firing  a 
transgender employee who was born a man because the employee 
began wearing stereotypical womenโs clothing. Id. at 1314. The 
employer  allowed  biological  women  to  wear  stereotypical 
womenโs clothing, but not biological men. We held that the em-
ployer had engaged in sex discrimination under the Equal Protec-
tion Clauseโnot because it fired a transgender employeeโbut be-
cause it fired an employee โon the basis of gender-based behavioral 
norms.โ Id. at 1316โ17. By ruling against that practice under the 
circumstances of that case, we required the employer to treat men 
and women equally, no matter their clothing choices.  
Unlike the employerโs decision in Glenn, Alabamaโs statute 
does not fit the mold of a sex-based stereotype. The statute isnโt 
based on a socially constructed generalization about the way men 
or women should behave. It does not reinforce an โassumption[] 
about the proper roles of men and womenโ in our society. Hogan, 
458 U.S. at 725โ26. And it doesnโt reflect societyโs โnotions of the 
relative capabilities of men and women.โ City of Cleburne, 473 U.S. 
at 441. To be sure, the statuteโs classification reflects the govern-
mentโs recognition that, without medical intervention, a healthy 
child will mature in accord with his or her biological sex. But the 
recognition of biological reality is โnot a stereotype.โ Nguyen v. INS, 
533 U.S. 53, 68 (2001). 
 
timeframe. One of the benefits of the appellate process is that we have more 
time and resources to assess a legal question, which sometimes yields a differ-
ent result. 
 

Case 2:22-cv-00184-LCB-CWB   Document 312   Filed 08/30/23   Page 58 of 65
USCA11 Case: 22-11707     Document: 125-1     Date Filed: 08/21/2023     Page: 56 of 59
22-11707   BRASHER, J., Concurring  7 
The district courtโviewing this case through the lens of sex 
stereotypingโdid not make any findings on whether the state was 
justified in treating people differently because they want these 
drugs to treat a discordance between their sex and gender identity 
instead of some other condition. But the state has identified many 
reasons for drawing that line. For example, the record reflects that 
other countries are regulating the drugs differently for these pur-
poses, and the FDA has not approved them for this purpose alt-
hough it has for others. I cannot say that those reasons fail the leni-
ent standard of rational basis review. See Jones v. Gov. of Fla., 975 
F.3d 1016, 1034โ35 (11th Cir. 2020). 
II.   
Although I believe rational basis scrutiny likely applies, I also 
think that, even if Alabamaโs statute triggered intermediate scru-
tiny, it would likely survive that heightened scrutiny.  
Intermediate scrutiny under the Equal Protection Clause 
does not require us to ask whether a law is good or bad policy, but 
whether a government has a good reason for using a sex-based clas-
sification in a law. The relevant question is whether โthe classifica-
tion serves โimportant governmental objectives and that the discrim-
inatory means employedโ are โsubstantially related to the achieve-
ment of those objectives.โโ Hogan, 458 U.S. at 724 (quoting Wengler 
v. Druggists Mutual Ins. Co., 446 U.S. 142, 150 (1980)) (emphasis 
added). As I discuss above, the purpose of this heightened scrutiny 
is to ensure that laws based on sex classifications arenโt using those 
classifications  because  of  โoutmoded  notions  of  the  relative 
 

Case 2:22-cv-00184-LCB-CWB   Document 312   Filed 08/30/23   Page 59 of 65
USCA11 Case: 22-11707     Document: 125-1     Date Filed: 08/21/2023     Page: 57 of 59
8  BRASHER, J., Concurring  22-11707 
capabilities of men and women.โ City of Cleburne, 473 U.S. at 441. 
Instead, the use of sex must reflect that it is a โmeaningful consid-
eration[]โ on which the law is based. Id. And so, under intermediate 
scrutiny, the governmentโs burden is to establish โan โexceedingly 
persuasive justificationโ for the classification.โ Hogan, 458 U.S. at 724 
(quoting Kirchberg v. Feenstra, 450 U.S. 455, 461 (1981)) (emphasis 
added).  
Assuming the classification in this law is subject to interme-
diate scrutiny, I believe the state probably has an โexceedingly per-
suasive justificationโ for regulating these drugs differently when 
they are used to treat a discordance between an individualโs sex and 
sense of gender identity than when they are used for other pur-
poses. See Sessions v. Morales-Santana, 582 U.S. 47, 58 (2017) (quot-
ing Virginia, 518 U.S. at 531). The record reflects that the use of 
puberty blockers and hormones for this purpose specifically carries 
potentially uncertain risks. The record also reflects that there is un-
certainty about how to tell which patients need these interventions 
for this purpose and which donโt. Although further fact finding in 
this litigation will test the plausibility of those concerns, Alabama 
doesnโt have to conclusively prove these things to have an im-
portant governmental interest. Intermediate scrutiny permits โthe 
legislature [to] make a predictive judgmentโ based on competing 
evidence.  Brown v. Entmโt Merchs. Assโn,  564  U.S.  786,  799โ800 
(2011) (discussing relative burdens of intermediate and strict scru-
tiny). 
 

Case 2:22-cv-00184-LCB-CWB   Document 312   Filed 08/30/23   Page 60 of 65
USCA11 Case: 22-11707     Document: 125-1     Date Filed: 08/21/2023     Page: 58 of 59
22-11707   BRASHER, J., Concurring  9 
Likewise, I think the stateโs interest is sufficiently related to 
the sex classification in the law to the extent there is one. Assuming 
this statute involves a sex-based classification, it does so because 
there is no other way to regulate treatments for a โdiscordance be-
tween [an individualโs] sex and their internal sense of identityโ 
without drawing such a distinction. Alabama would have to use 
sex-based language to regulate those treatments even if it wanted 
to subsidize them instead of banning them. So, if intermediate scru-
tiny applied here, the โsufficiently relatedโ question collapses into 
the state interest question: it is whether Alabama has an important 
governmental interest in regulating the use of puberty blockers and 
hormones for a โdiscordance between [an individualโs] sex and 
their internal sense of identityโ but not for other uses. Because the 
record reflects that the state has that kind of interest, the statuteโs 
classification likely satisfies intermediate scrutiny.  
The plaintiffs argue, in part, that Alabama is not justified in 
banning these treatments because there are less restrictive alterna-
tives to a ban. But I donโt think that is how intermediate scrutiny 
works under the Equal Protection Clause. Consider how the Su-
preme Court applied intermediate scrutiny in Craig v. Boren, 429 
U.S. 190 (1976). There, a state law prohibited sales of alcohol to 
men between the ages of eighteen and twenty but not women in 
that age range. Id. at 191โ92. The Court accepted that the goal of 
this lawโโthe enhancement of traffic safetyโโis an important in-
terest. Id. at 199โ200. But it held that the government did not have 
sufficient evidence that a โgender-based distinction closely serves 
to achieve that objective.โ Id. at 200. The Court in Craig never 
 

Case 2:22-cv-00184-LCB-CWB   Document 312   Filed 08/30/23   Page 61 of 65
USCA11 Case: 22-11707     Document: 125-1     Date Filed: 08/21/2023     Page: 59 of 59
10  BRASHER, J., Concurring  22-11707 
asked whether the stateโs decision to ban under-21-year-old men 
from drinking alcohol was justified as compared to some less re-
strictive, but equally sex-based, alternativeโsuch as making men 
take additional driving classes or the like. Instead, the Court as-
sessed only whether the sex-based classification fit closely enough to 
the purposes of the law. Likewise, here, I think we can resolve the 
plaintiffsโ equal protection claim by assessing whether the state has 
an interest in classifying based on sex without also asking whether, 
even if the state were allowed to classify based on sex, the state 
could achieve its objective with some lesser restriction. 
In short, assuming this law is subject to intermediate scru-
tiny, I think it likely passes. On this record, it seems clear that the 
state has an interest in regulating these drugs differently when they 
are prescribed to treat a discordance between sex and gender than 
when they are prescribed to treat other conditions. And the state 
cannot do that without drawing the lines it has drawn in this stat-
ute. 
III.   
Whether rational basis or intermediate scrutiny applies, I be-
lieve this appeal comes out the same way: the state will likely pre-
vail on the merits. Future findings of fact in the district court may 
establish otherwise. But at this stage, the plaintiffs have not carried 
their burden entitling them to a preliminary injunction. I concur.
